source.9338488b:
#importing libraries
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.1eea8ff7:
#importing dataset and declaring independent and dependent variable
#the dependent variable is in last column, hence y is assigned with [:,-1] (meaning all rows of last column)
ds = pd.read_csv('../input/salary/Salary.csv')
x = ds.iloc[:,:-1].values
y = ds.iloc[:,-1].values
source.aff0fb2e:
#splitting dataset in training and testing set
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(x,y, test_size = 0.2, random_state = 0)
source.1be8e6b8:
#training the model
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
lr = LinearRegression()
lr.fit(x_train,y_train)
source.2f8f44da:
#visualising training test results
plt.scatter(x_train,y_train,c = 'red')
plt.plot(x_train, lr.predict(x_train))
plt.xlabel('number of years')
plt.ylabel('salary')
plt.title('visualising training test results')
source.58a4b491:
#visualising test set results
plt.scatter(x_test,y_test,c = 'red')
plt.plot(x_train, lr.predict(x_train))
plt.xlabel('number of years')
plt.ylabel('salary')
plt.title('visualising test set results')
source.bd90a145:
#finding equation of linear regression
c = lr.intercept_
m = lr.coef_
print('equation of linear regression - y = {}x + {}'.format(m,c))
source.1ce52e49:
#getting accuracy of the model
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
r2_score(y_test,lr.predict(x_test))
source.37411c0e: **THE ACCURACY FOR THE MODEL CAME OUT TO BE 97% WHICH IS PRETTY GOOD.**
source.42d35237: no categorical data and no missing values
source.8adcf2de:
A Simple Linear Regression model for predicting salaries of the people according to their years of experience, more work experience means more salary.
Dataset consists of two features(years of experience is independent and other salary is dependent)
